questions.question: Electric field
choices: (a) is always perpendicular to equipotential surfaces
(b) is always parallel to equipotential surfaces
(c) does not have a specific orientation with respect to equipotential surfaces
(d) is something I learned in January, but not really sure what it is and how it relates to anything
questions.answer: (a) is always perpendicular to equipotential surfaces
questions.explanation: Electric field lines are always perpendicular to equipotential surfaces because no work is done moving along an equipotential surface.

questions.question: An electron volt is
choices: (a) the force acting on an electron in a field of 1 N/C
(b) the force required to move an electron 1 meter
(c) the energy gained by an electron in moving through a potential difference of 1 volt
(d) the energy needed to move an electron through 1 meter in any electric field
(e) the work done when 1 coulomb of charge is moved through a potential difference of 1 volt
questions.answer: (c) the energy gained by an electron in moving through a potential difference of 1 volt
questions.explanation: 1 eV = 1.6 × 10⁻¹⁹ J. It's the kinetic energy gained by a single electron when accelerated through a potential difference of 1 volt.

questions.question: The fact that we can define electric potential means that
choices: (c) the work done on a charged particle depends on the path it takes
(d) there is a point where the electric potential energy is exactly zero
(e) Dr. Maravin makes very hard quizzes
questions.explanation: Only conservative forces allow us to define potential energy. The work done by conservative forces is path-independent.

questions.question: A tiny sphere carrying a charge of 6.5 µC sits in an electric field, at a point where the electric potential is 240 V. What's the sphere's potential energy?
The work required to carry a particle with a charge of 6.0 µC from a 5.0 V equipotential surface to a 6.0 V equipotential surface and back again to the 5.0 V surface is:
questions.explanation: Since the particle returns to its starting point, the net work done by a conservative force is zero. The work for a closed path is always zero for conservative forces.

questions.question: Which quantity or quantities take on the same value on all points of a good conductor?
choices: (d) surface charge density and normal component of electric field
(e) normal component of electric field and voltage
questions.explanation: In electrostatic equilibrium, a conductor is an equipotential - all points have the same voltage. Surface charge density varies with local curvature.

questions.question: Each plate of a capacitor stores a charge of magnitude 1 mC when a 100 V potential difference is applied. The capacitance is
If the charge on a parallel-plate capacitor is doubled
choices: (e) the surface charge density is not changed on either plate
questions.explanation: Capacitance depends only on geometry. $E = \frac{\sigma}{\epsilon_0}$, and if Q doubles, σ doubles, so E doubles.

questions.question: Dielectric filling in the capacitor
choices: (a) reduces the electric field in the capacitor
(b) increases the electric field in the capacitor
(c) inserted to protect the capacitor from the discharge
questions.answer: (a) reduces the electric field in the capacitor
questions.explanation: Dielectric material reduces the electric field by a factor of κ (dielectric constant), allowing more charge storage at the same voltage.

questions.question: A fuse is a piece of conductor designed to heat up and break when the current through it exceeds some rated value. To protect a circuit, it should be wired
choices: (a) in series with the rest of the circuit
(b) in parallel with the rest of the circuit
(c) either in series or in parallel, as the fuse will protect the circuit no matter where it is connected
questions.answer: (a) in series with the rest of the circuit
questions.explanation: A fuse must be in series so that all circuit current flows through it. If wired in parallel, the current would bypass the fuse.

questions.question: What is the resistance of the 100W light bulb when operating at V = 120 V?

A compact fluorescent bulb produces the same light output as a 60 W conventional bulb, but it consumes ten times less power. How many of these bulbs can be put in parallel on a V = 120 V circuit protected by a 15A circuit breaker?
questions.explanation: Each bulb uses $P = 60/10 = 6\,\mathrm{W}$. Total power: $P_{max} = 120 \times 15 = 1800\,\mathrm{W}$. Number of bulbs: $1800/6 = 300$

questions.question: An ideal battery has an EMF of 12 V. If it is connected to a circuit and creates a current of 4.0 A, what is the power that battery produces?
choices: (e) cannot tell without knowing the resistance of the circuit

questions.question: The EMF of a battery is equal to its terminal potential difference
choices: (b) only when the battery is being charged
(c) only when a large current is in the battery
(d) only when there is no current in the battery
questions.answer: (d) only when there is no current in the battery
questions.explanation: When current flows, the terminal voltage drops due to internal resistance: $V = \mathcal{E} - Ir$. When $I = 0$, $V = \mathcal{E}$.

questions.question: "The sum of the currents into a junction equals the sum of the currents out of the junction" is a consequence of
questions.explanation: Kirchhoff's Current Law (KCL) is based on conservation of charge - charge cannot accumulate at a junction.

questions.question: The time constant RC has units of
Here is a loop equation: $R_1 I + \frac{Q}{C} = \mathcal{E}$. What does this equation represent?
choices: (c) a capacitor that has been disconnected
questions.explanation: This is the loop equation for an RC charging circuit. As Q increases, the voltage across C increases until it equals $\mathcal{E}$.

questions.question:
Evil Dr. Maravin needs extra energy to make an extra difficult quiz 2 problem, so he decides to make himself a cup of coffee using a copper heating element made from wire with diameter 2 mm and length 20 meters rolled into a spiral. He uses a car battery providing 12 V.
• (a) (2 points) Calculate the resistance of the heating element assuming that the resistivity of copper is 1.68 × 10⁻⁸ Ω·m.
• (b) (2 points) When Dr. Maravin plugs the heating element to the car battery he is surprised that the heating elements does not get really hot! Annoyed, he measures the potential difference across the heating element to find out that only 2 V is on the heating element, despite the fact that the battery is rated at 12V. What is the reason for such a small potential difference on the heating element? (Hint: the car battery is not ideal.)
• (c) (2 points) Calculate the internal resistance of the battery.
• (d) (2 points) What is the power of the thermal energy in the heating element? Compare that to the usual 800W appliance that is commonly used to heat water.

questions.question:
In a circuit with three resistors and two voltage sources, $I_1$, $I_2$, and $I_3$ are the currents flowing through resistors $R_1$, $R_2$, and $R_3$.
• (a) (3 points) Deduce three independent equations for the three unknown currents. Use symbolic notation for resistances and voltages.
• (b) (6 points) Take V1 = 20V, V2 = 10V; R2 = 10^6 Ω, and R1 = R3 = R4 = 100 Ω. Calculate I1, I2, and I3. You can use equations above, or if you can see a simpler path to a very good estimate of the exact answer, use it, explaining whatever approximation you make in one sentence. (Hint: Wow! R2 is a very big resistance!)
• (c) (2 points) What is the potential difference between points A and B: VB - VA?

questions.question:
In a circuit, $\mathcal{E} = 12\,\mathrm{V}$, $R_1 = R_2 = R_3 = 1000\,\Omega$. With the capacitor C completely uncharged, the switch S is suddenly closed (at t = 0).

• (b) (2 points) What are the currents through the above-mentioned resistors at a very long time t = ∞ after the switch is closed?
